results.title: Faces of India: Raju, a guide from Rishikesh
results.creator_credit: Yavar Abbas and Face Film Productions
results.brief_description: Gives an intimate insight into the lives of the ordinary people in Rishikesh in the Himalayan foothills. The film follows a nine-year-old boy through a day’s work taking visitors around the town. We hear Raju giving facts and figures and details of everything he sees. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Fairy tale: a true story
results.creator_credit: Charles Sturridge, Bruce Davey, Wendy Finerman and Anna K Productions
results.brief_description: In 1917 two English girls, Elise Wright and Frances Griffiths photographed fairies in their garden. These photographs became known as the Cottingley photographs, eponymous from the village where the girls lived. This led to the often asked question, “do fairies exist?”. This event led to a nation wide search for the truth, led by two personalities of the day, Harry Houdini (Harvey Keitel), and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle (Peter O’Toole). Although this film is based on a true event; the existence of the photographs, the film’s ending does differ from the truth that eventuated much later. A magical tale that will enchant viewers of all ages. Cast includes Florence Hoath, Elizabeth Earl, Paul McGann and Phoebe Nicholls.

results.title: Fair play
results.creator_credit: Susan Lambert, Janet Bell and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Australian women cricketers are the undisputed world-cup cricket champions in a sport which is hotly contested by nine affiliated countries. This film follows their latest tour to England to play on the hallowed grounds at Lords.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Susan Lambert, Janet Bell and Film Australia

results.title: Failing to learn, learning to fail (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Mike Gavin, Films Incorporated and National Broadcasting Company
results.brief_description: Investigates the relationship between learning disabilities and delinquent behaviour by examining the history of four youngsters afflicted with minimal brain dysfunction. Points out the importance of early diagnosis and reports on the progress being made in the treatment of this disorder.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mike Gavin, Films Incorporated and National Broadcasting Company

results.title: Fahrenheit 9/11
results.creator_credit: Michael Moore, Kathleen Glynn, Jim Czarnecki, Lions Gate Films, The Fellowship Adventure Group, IFC Productions (US) and Dog Eat Dog Films
results.brief_description: The heat is up in this award-winning documentary made by maverick dissident Michael Moore (“Bowling for Columbine”) with his sharp wit and biting commentary on the United States’ Government and contemporary America. President George W. Bush bares the brunt of this filmmaker’s wrath as Moore, with his sense of humour intact, sets about to make clear to the world American foreign policy and its consequences. This is the sort of filmmaking that gets people thinking, talking and hopefully, taking action. Not only did “Fahrenheit 9/11” win awards but its popularity with the cinema-going public created a record at the box office for a documentary film and paved the way for other works in the genre to be more prominent in the cinema exhibition market. Winner of Best Picture at Cannes 2004.

results.title: Face of the Earth
results.creator_credit: Bill Mason, Wolf Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film explores the origin of our planet’s outer layer, the why-and-how of its mobility. Through the use of well designed diagrams, the earth’s cyclical activity is clearly explained. Some unusual footage on volcanoes give added punch to an already absorbing subject. (Awards: Cleveland; New York). Credits include: Animation by Eva Szasz; sound by Larry Crosley, Karl Duplessis; photography by Bill Mason, Simon LeBlanc; music by David Green.

results.title: Face
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This film is a visual experiment, an exploration into the past, present and projected life of a young woman as seen on her face. A broad range of emotions are held up to the camera, both rehearsed and unrehearsed by this professional actress Julie Wildman. (Award: Niagara-on-the-Lake). Photography by Robin Spry and Kjeld Nielsen, sound by John Knight.

results.title: Fabienne
results.creator_credit: Jacques Godbout, Andre Belleau and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: She is a night club entertainer, in her way a highly successful exponent of her art, but there are moments when the admiration of her Montreal following is not enough. “Fabienne” is the portrait of a woman who has achieved enviable fame but is still far from content. (Award: Evian) Credits include: photographer by Guy Borremans; editing by Jacques Godbout, Gilles Groulx; music by Pierre Letourneau and sound by Joseph Champagne.

results.title: Fab noir
results.creator_credit: Phillip Healy, Jack White, Christine Wardale, Debbie Packham and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: The acrid smell of stale socks hung heavily in the air - Clay motions to open the window but the phone rings. 2am was always a bad time to die. Cast includes Peter Moon, Peter Stretton.

results.title: Factory inspector
results.creator_credit: Julien Aunter, Dick Andrews, Jim Davies, Leonard Reeve and Anglo-Scottish Pictures
results.brief_description: Approximately 100 years ago (c1848) the Factory Inspectorate was created in England, and with it came laws and regulations designed to safeguard the factory worker. The duties of a factory inspector include the inspection of safety devices and guards on various machines; checking the aprons and gloves of working men; observing the condition and operation of equipment used in the loading and unloading of ships; interviewing a witness of an industrial accident.
